text.p: Sun Microsystems Inc chairman Scott McNealy said on Friday that the company would consider further share buy-backs and "opportunistic" acquisitions.
"Before the cash horde gets too big, we would probably continue to invest in ourselves," McNealy told Reuters in an interview.
Sun had cash and short-term investments of about US$1.0 billion at June 30, 1996 and almost no debt, he said.

"We haven't done much with our financies, except buy our own stock back and it has turned out to be a stunning investment for our shareholders," said McNealy, who is on a 10-day visit to Australia and New Zealand.

In August, Sun directors approved a systematic repurchase programme, which enabled the group to repurchase in the open market a portion of shares of common stock which it expects to issue under its 1990 Long-Term Equity Incentive Plan.
The amount of repurchases under this programme would not exceed $450 million over the next three years.
McNealy, who is also president and chief executive officer of Sun, said the company had bought close to US$2 billion worth of its stock on the market since it was founded in 1982.
Asked whether the Mountain View, California-based company was considering any acqusitions, McNealy replied: "We will be opportunistic." He said he could not be specific.
McNealy said he could not comment on Sun's 1996/97 first quarter results, which are to be released on Tuesday.
Sun reported earnings per share of $0.85 in the first quarter of 1995/96. Sun shares closed 50 cents higher at $66, just off its high of $67-3/4 hit on earlier in Thursday trade.
"It hasn't closed at $66 very often," McNealy said.
The stock has traded between $36 and $67-3/4 this year.
